question: Question_07_(b)
statement:
Suppose that \emph{A} is a symmetric 4x4 matrix with eigenvalues 0, 1,
4, 5. Define a sequence of vectors $\mathbf{x}_n \in \mathbb{R}^4$ by
choosing \textbf{x}\textsubscript{0} at random, and then settings

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{y}_n &= (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf{x}_{n-1} \\
\mathbf{x}_n &= \mathbf{y}_n/\|\mathbf{y}_{n}\|
\end{align*}

for \emph{n = 1, 2, ...}. You then observe that
\textbf{x}\textsubscript{n} converges to

\[\mathbf{x}_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T\]

as $n \to \infty$.

\textbf{(b)} What is the value of the inner (dot) product
$\langle \mathbf{x}_\infty, A\mathbf{x}_\infty\rangle$?
sols:
From part (a), we recall that $\displaystyle \lambda = 4$ was the
eigenvalue associated to the eigenvector $\displaystyle x_{\infty}$. We
can use these to find the solution:

\begin{align*}
Ax_{\infty} &= \lambda x_{\infty}\\
Ax_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty} &= \lambda x_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty}\\
Ax_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty} &= 4(1)\\
\langle \mathbf{x}_\infty, A\mathbf{x}_\infty\rangle &= 4
\end{align*}
hints:
Recall that from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_07_(a)}{part
(a)} that $\displaystyle A\mathbf x_{\infty} = 4\mathbf x_{\infty}$.
